text:
Hi everyone. Tej here from *Hubilo*, a virtual events platform with a mission to enable deep human interactions and engagement for your events 

I joined as the lead responsible for content leadership in the team. One of the challenges I need to break down is to how to decide on the scope of content and forms and a general information architecture which educates and engages. Has anyone here worked on a content planning exercise for a product that multiple use cases, personas? I would love to learn from you.

Where do I get started when initiating a content planning exercise which can serve content for a range of personas and use cases

elements.text: Hi everyone. Tej here from
Hubilo

, a virtual events platform with a mission to enable deep human interactions and engagement for your events 

I joined as the lead responsible for content leadership in the team. One of the challenges I need to break down is to how to decide on the scope of content and forms and a general information architecture which educates and engages. Has anyone here worked on a content planning exercise for a product that multiple use cases, personas? I would love to learn from you.

Where do I get started when initiating a content planning exercise which can serve content for a range of personas and use cases

text: I'd suggest starting with the list of most buring pain point of each persona. Once you have this, you can start mapping use cases that answer to these needs. From there, you can break down each use case to a series of articles -- each with different angle on the same problem.

elements.text: I'd suggest starting with the list of most buring pain point of each persona. Once you have this, you can start mapping use cases that answer to these needs. From there, you can break down each use case to a series of articles -- each with different angle on the same problem.

text: Thanks. that's well said. When new into a market, how do I get framing of the pain point right when researching. Don't want it to be defined by SEO keywords. How do I understand the size of pain point and prioritise what to write first?

elements.text: Thanks. that's well said. When new into a market, how do I get framing of the pain point right when researching. Don't want it to be defined by SEO keywords. How do I understand the size of pain point and prioritise what to write first?

text:
that is the question :wink: A well-created persona should have the painpoints outlined, but I know that's not always possible.

There are various tactics to get the knowledge you need -- depending on how well your niche is defined. The ideal would be to talk with the prospects, conduct interviews/surveys. The next best thing is social listening [groups, reddit, twitter, etc.] Answerthepublic did a couple of webinars on it, maybe <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41nfJTDnX6w|this> can give you a hint.

attachments.title: Search Listening: How observing online behaviour can help you produce better content
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Search Listening: How observing online behaviour can help you produce better content

text: Thanks for the direction. I am happy to share that the first thing i did was to listen to sales calls, and send a hi mail to customers that I want to learn from them. But yes, one email ain't cutting it. Have to be persistent, try different ways of asking and get to their answer.

text: Do you look up to any B2B companies who get the understanding of customer pain point so right that it gives the chills? Especially in their awareness/consideration stage content. (blog/ebooks/webinars etc) Happy to read your own content if you can share which you feel got the pulse so right

text: Unfortunately no sources in the B2B area come to my mind. In my experience, getting customers to talk with you is the most difficult part because they're so busy :wink: But once you have a F2F conversation, they tend to be really open about their problems. You can also check social media channels and websites of the customers -- nobody is talking about challenges, but their successes can tell you a bit about what they are aming for.

elements.text: Unfortunately no sources in the B2B area come to my mind. In my experience, getting customers to talk with you is the most difficult part because they're so busy

But once you have a F2F conversation, they tend to be really open about their problems. You can also check social media channels and websites of the customers -- nobody is talking about challenges, but their successes can tell you a bit about what they are aming for.

text: Does it have a ready-made audience of subscriber-readers and/or do you expect that people will consume it like a periodical?  If the answer to one or both of those is yes, then I'd say a meta-post about the blog makes sense.  If the answer to both is no, then it might just be shouting into the void

text: Hello, folks.  I'm doing a little bit of light market research.  For anyone with experience outsourcing social content creation, what have you paid, and what has been the deliverable?  I'm interested in general, but most specifically for LinkedIn and Twitter.

elements.text: Hello, folks.  I'm doing a little bit of light market research.  For anyone with experience outsourcing social content creation, what have you paid, and what has been the deliverable?  I'm interested in general, but most specifically for LinkedIn and Twitter.

text: I would probably go straight into the post as well. A letter from the editor won’t really rank on Google. I know that’s not the purpose of all content, but it’s fairly important. If you decide to share it with your email list, you can certainly write them a letter from the editor when you share the first few pieces with them.

elements.text: I would probably go straight into the post as well. A letter from the editor won’t really rank on Google. I know that’s not the purpose of all content, but it’s fairly important. If you decide to share it with your email list, you can certainly write them a letter from the editor when you share the first few pieces with them.

text: One approach: You write the editor’s letter for you, not for the audience (at first). It’ll serve as a nice “manifesto” to help guide your future coverage AND give you something to link to in the future.

elements.text: One approach: You write the editor’s letter for you, not for the audience (at first). It’ll serve as a nice “manifesto” to help guide your future coverage AND give you something to link to in the future.

text:

Especially if they’re not really into the product they’re marketing.

We didn't win that one. : ) Curious what others will think of your question too.

text:
How long after publishing a post do y'all wait on average to see if it'll rank on the first page or if you need to update it?

I'm asking because I typically wait 2-6 months for a post to appear on the first page prior to revising (in part because I often forget to check back... but also depending on competitiveness) but was wondering if anyone else had any stricter guidelines that they followed

elements.text:
How long after publishing a post do y'all wait on average to see if it'll rank on the first page or if you need to update it?

I'm asking because I typically wait 2-6 months for a post to appear on the first page prior to revising (in part because I often forget to check back... but also depending on competitiveness) but was wondering if anyone else had any stricter guidelines that they followed

text: I check ~3-4 weeks after publishing to see where it ended up. I’ll look in the top ~50 (and use a keyword tracker for additional insights).

elements.text: I check ~3-4 weeks after publishing to see where it ended up. I’ll look in the top ~50 (and use a keyword tracker for additional insights).

text: Then I’ll start benchmarking against folks above me. If I’m 30th, what do 10th and 20th look like in terms of content length, backlinks, internal linking, etc.

elements.text: Then I’ll start benchmarking against folks above me. If I’m 30th, what do 10th and 20th look like in terms of content length, backlinks, internal linking, etc.

text: From there, chop wood and carry water (and periodically revisit the rankings)

elements.text: From there, chop wood and carry water (and periodically revisit the rankings)

text: We have a projection model for time to rank based (I'm oversimplifying slightly) on domain authority and search term competitiveness.  Anything out of the top 3 spots and beyond the timeline of "expected time to rank," we'd refresh.

elements.text: We have a projection model for time to rank based (I'm oversimplifying slightly) on domain authority and search term competitiveness.  Anything out of the top 3 spots and beyond the timeline of "expected time to rank," we'd refresh.

text: i think it works best for marketing oriented posts. if you're not in that world, not as great of a distro channel imo

elements.text: i think it works best for marketing oriented posts. if you're not in that world, not as great of a distro channel imo

text: Absent running through that model, we'd give it six months and then refresh if it's between spots 4 and 15 (unless a client likes to gamble, then we might do spots 2 or 3)

elements.text: Absent running through that model, we'd give it six months and then refresh if it's between spots 4 and 15 (unless a client likes to gamble, then we might do spots 2 or 3)

text: <@UJG24P8P6> we're currently tuning it and getting ready to put it out as a tool to help with traffic projections.  It was initially something we were using to help early stage founders make the case for funding/content investment, but we're thinking it has broader interest/appeal.  I'm not a statistician, but we've essentially used an exponential model (like compound interest) for traffic and tuned the coefficients to make the data fit over a number of clients' historical data

elements.text: we're currently tuning it and getting ready to put it out as a tool to help with traffic projections. I'm not a statistician, but we've essentially used an exponential model (like compound interest) for traffic and tuned the coefficients to make the data fit over a number of clients' historical data

text:
We did a rebrand last summer and had the team change linkedin banners, add branded frames to their linkedin headshots, post on twitter (we had them share a blog we wrote explaining the new brand). Since we were changing our logo, etc. in addition to the website we ensured everyone changed email signatures, etc.

We made it a game and offered folks points for taking more advanced steps i.e. video on linkedin instead of a post. Employees were divided into teams and had tasks like commenting on each others linkedin posts to boost their visibility in the algorithm. The team that did each of the required tasks first got a prize and then the team with the most points got a prize

elements.text:
We did a rebrand last summer and had the team change linkedin banners, add branded frames to their linkedin headshots, post on twitter (we had them share a blog we wrote explaining the new brand). Since we were changing our logo, etc. in addition to the website we ensured everyone changed email signatures, etc.

We made it a game and offered folks points for taking more advanced steps i.e. video on linkedin instead of a post. Employees were divided into teams and had tasks like commenting on each others linkedin posts to boost their visibility in the algorithm. The team that did each of the required tasks first got a prize and then the team with the most points got a prize

text: I'm guessing they're already engaged with your content, versus if your blog is only for search. That way you can be transparent about your processes, share your work, and why you're starting a blog then. they'd be the most interested imo

elements.text: I'm guessing they're already engaged with your content, versus if your blog is only for search. That way you can be transparent about your processes, share your work, and why you're starting a blog then. they'd be the most interested imo

elements.text: I love that idea! Thank you!

text: The team aspect definitely helped us get some of our less-brand savvy team members to switch things over like software engineers, etc. Since our customers are more likely to be connected to their account managers on linkedin, email than following our corporate account (just because of the nature of corporate accounts on linkedin and their devaluation in the algorithm) it was really important to us that team members were sharing, not just from our company accounts

text:
When you're researching the industry/company/competitors etc., like when you first start a new role in a different area — do you have a system for collecting insights? Besides just keeping paper notes or one big document (I'm interested in both tools and manner of categorization).

I'm doing a lot of reading, browsing subreddits, etc., and getting lots of thoughts and ideas but it feels like I'm not outputting anything - I'm worried I'm going to forget everything and I'll have wasted all that research time!

elements.text:
When you're researching the industry/company/competitors etc., like when you first start a new role in a different area — do you have a system for collecting insights? Besides just keeping paper notes or one big document (I'm interested in both tools and manner of categorization).

I'm doing a lot of reading, browsing subreddits, etc., and getting lots of thoughts and ideas but it feels like I'm not outputting anything - I'm worried I'm going to forget everything and I'll have wasted all that research time!

text: I have a variety of ways of keeping up with ideas. It just depends on what’s most convenient for me at the time. Sometimes it’s a sticky note, the notes app on my phone, or a Google sheets file with all of my ideas. I’ve also been really into using Notion lately, but mostly for my side projects since my coworkers don’t use it.

elements.text: I have a variety of ways of keeping up with ideas. It just depends on what’s most convenient for me at the time. Sometimes it’s a sticky note, the notes app on my phone, or a Google sheets file with all of my ideas. I’ve also been really into using Notion lately, but mostly for my side projects since my coworkers don’t use it.

text:
I’d collect everything on something like Notion, and I’d first start researching by talking to colleagues to get the lay of the land. Especially customer facing roles like sales and support/CSM Then move to customers from there.

Once you have all that, supplement with what you’re finding online. Talking to some well known folks that have a good understanding of the industry really helps too.

elements.text:

text: My company would like to create a sort of employer branding video where we interview members of our team (at home over zoom or another video chat platform) about our company values and then compile little snippets of their responses and fashion it together into a video we would share on our Careers page. Given the constraints of having to do this all virtually, is it worth hiring a contractor or agency to work on this project? What sort of value-add can they provide in this instance? And if yes, any good recs??? :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I would probably make a habit of going through and setting an hour or so on my calendar each week to reading through what I saved and figuring out how to use it or if it’s relevant to what I want to accomplish. Maybe give yourself a rule that you need to figure out how to implement at least one thing you read each week. It’s easy to collect but you need time to synthesize and act on whatever your reading.

text: <@UKAK6J1NY> So maybe the "letter from the editor" is something you create as a segue from the podcast to the blog?  IOW, you could add it to the podcast's show notes with a CTA like "check out our blog" and perhaps start mentioning it in future episodes.  It feels like you could let that concept (transitioning listeners to readers) steer the letter from the editor -- why should listeners read the blog?  Your "north star" material then becomes the answer to that question.
